body:
The Go project has not "closed the door" on China. Quite the opposite. The change was motivated by a desire to reach *more* Chinese uses, not to discriminate against them.

Quoting @jbuberel replying to @minux from [the original change](https://go-review.googlesource.com/#/c/14190/):

> > Why do we block sharing requests from Chinese users?
Is there a policy for this? Thanks.
> > And I think the reason Chinese users are not able
to access *.golang.org is not due to IP based
blocking at Google's side. Each and every one of
Google's public IP is being black-holed by a
famous firewall.
> 
> You are correct in that Chinese users are unable to access *.golang.org sites because those network blocks have been firewalled by the GFC. However, Google does have several network blocks that have not yet been black-holed from which the *.golang.org services can be served. 
>
> But in order for that to happen, we are required to ensure that we do not permit the *.golang.org sites to be used for creating User Generated Content by Chinese internet users in accordance with those laws. And the Go Playground was highlighted as a method of creating User Generated Content that could get the sites banned explicitly. 

I hope we can agree that it is better for Chinese users to be able to access golang.org, even if that means they can't share or retrieve shared playground snippets.
